li.p: if an asset’s net selling price is higher than its value in use, a rational enterprise will dispose of the asset. In this situation, it is logical to base recoverable amount on the asset’s net selling price to avoid recognising an impairment loss that is unrelated to economic reality.

if an asset’s net selling price is greater than its value in use, but management decides to keep the asset, the extra loss (the difference between net selling price and value in use) properly falls in later periods because it results from management’s decision in these later periods to keep the asset.
